posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
Hey Everyone,

Relatively new to training PIDs and working on an arm pid following the Talon’s motion magic guide:

Primer on Closed-loop: Talon SRX and Victor SPX supports a variety of closed-loop modes including position closed-loop, velocity closed-loop, Motion Profiling, and Motion Magic. Talon SRX additiona...

The arm works relatively well (I can get within 10 degrees of target position), however I feel like it could be better, so I wanted to go through my process.

In my case, we chose to had the arm being completely horizontal be 0 ticks on the encoder. Following the tutorial guidance, we set up the coefficient to basically make encoder ticks a 1 to 1 with degrees. So when the encoder position reads 90, the arm is at the top of the circle sticking straight up in the air. Encoder Position is 0 and 180 at the horizontal positions.

When it comes to tuning the maximum gravity feed forward, following the guide I found that I needed to run the motor at 20% to be able to hold the 0 horizontal position. So I chose to use a maximumGravityFeedForward of .20. Which with my understanding the cos(0) will be 1, meaning it will maximize the gravityFeedForward at the horizontal positions.

kf Here is where my understanding of PID is fuzzy. First for setting the KF, from my understanding this would be the maximum speed the PID loop would be allowed to run at.

I found that 30% motor output was a good speed.  Using the scaled values, I found the encoder was moving at 7 units per 100ms. This is obviously the scaled value which tries to be 1 to 1 to degrees. Now thinking about it, I wonder if I should be using native units for this value. But anyways, using that math:

(30% * 1023) / (7) = 43.8428571429 kF

kp Next is kP. From my understanding, this is what we allow the loop to respond to the error.  In this case I used 20% which is 3 units/100ms

(20% * 1023) / (3) = 68.2 kP

Does my understanding of this process make sense? I feel like I am doing something wrong, I wanted to run it by people here who have a much better understanding of how this works. I haven’t even begun to change kD and kI yet, as from my understanding kD to resolve overshoot and for kI to help smooth

link_counts.title: Motor Controller Closed Loop — Phoenix documentation

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
The kF feedforward supported by motion magic is strictly proportional to the setpoint.  For position control, this almost never makes sense.  This is an especially poor approach for controlling a mechanism whose feedforward dynamics are nonlinear (like an arm that has a cosine-dependent force acting on it at all times).

Consider instead characterizing your arm with SysId (or computing the relevant gains theoretically from the design) and using WPILib’s ArmFeedforward class.

Plumbing this into MotionMagic may prove not-very-ergonomic (I’ve done it in the past - it was possible but not fun), so I’d also recommend abandoning MotionMagic entirely and just generating your profiles on the RIO .

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
ah so your saying even when using Motion magic I shouldn’t use a KF? The docs imply you need it though…

My takeaway was MotionMagic was somehow different than KF

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
It seems that the CTRE lib multiplies kF by the velocity setpoint rather than the position setpoint in MotionMagic mode, which is more sensible (I have not used it in several years) but still far from ideal to control an arm (whose feedforward is predominantly proportional to the cosine of the horizontal angle).

To be explicit, the full first-order governing equation for an arm is:

\ddot{\theta}(t) = -\frac{K_v}{K_a}\dot{\theta}(t) + \frac{1}{K_a}U(t) + \frac{K_g}{K_a}\cos(\theta)

where \theta is the angle of the arm from horizontal, U is the input voltage, and the constants are those in the WPILib ArmFeedforward.  The dominant term in this equation is usually the \cos(\theta) term.  The kF feedforward includes only the \dot{\theta} term ( kF is equal to K_v ).

posts.name: Jacob Caporuscio
posts.cooked:
Yes, kF in our closed-loop documentation is equivalent to Kv - you’ll see it documented as Velocity Feed-Forward for this reason. It’s also a configured value which means it really shouldn’t be changed on-the-fly like a generic feed-forward accounting for gravity.

For a general feed-forward, use the arbitrary feed-forward functionality.

Primer on Closed-loop: Talon SRX and Victor SPX supports a variety of closed-loop modes including position closed-loop, velocity closed-loop, Motion Profiling, and Motion Magic. Talon SRX additiona...

There’s even fairly straightforward examples for gravity offsets with arms.

Primer on Closed-loop: Talon SRX and Victor SPX supports a variety of closed-loop modes including position closed-loop, velocity closed-loop, Motion Profiling, and Motion Magic. Talon SRX additiona...

If you want to not use the config “kF” term you could also set it as 0 and then include your velocity feed-forward in the arbitrary feed-forward term, that’s up to you.

posts.name: Eli Barnett
posts.cooked:
Yeah, I’d advise getting rid of kF and using one of the WPILib feedforward classes to pipe to your arbitraryFeedForward parameter (be aware of the necessary rescaling from voltage to [-1,1] ).

Or, you could use WPILib functionality for the trajectory/feedback portions, as well, and have the whole API agree on units.

posts.name: joemost
Jacob Caporuscio
posts.cooked:
joemost:

Do my calculations for kF and kP makes sense? Feels odd to have a value greater than 0

Both of those values seem high.

Keep in mind that any time you’re using speed in your calculations (such as for kF) you should use the raw native units, not the value that’s scaled to degrees.

I would recommend the following for using Motion Magic with your arm:

Determine you arbitrary feed-forward first, before calculating any of your gains.  Use just percent output mode + arbitrary feed-forward to make sure you can control your arm with a joystick and have it stay at position as expected.  This will validate that your gravity compensation from feed-forward is working.

Then start tuning your gains, beginning with kF as the velocity feed-forward, making sure to use raw native units in your calculations.

It is possible that your gains may end up greater than 1, it just depends on the arm system.

joemost:

Was there any example of that arm with gravity in your repo anywhere?

It doesn’t look like there is one in the examples repo - most of the examples are drivetrain based.

I’ll also add that when motion magic was released there was no WPI functionality for an automatic trapezoidal profile or (if I recall correctly, I could be wrong) feed-forward classes - there’s a lot of cool functionality that’s been added in the last couple of years.  Using the WPI features is completely viable if you choose.

I think that you should be able to get up and running with motion magic fairly quickly using what I outlined above, just keep your units in mind. If you run into any issues you can respond here or email us: support@ctr-electronics.com

posts.cooked:

AH! okay. Yup. I was using my value that scaled to degrees! Woops! I’ll retry measuring for native  units.

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked:
Thanks! One last question…

When finding that arbitrary feedforward, I found there were values that would ‘hold’ the arm at the horizontal, but I needed a greater value to allow the arm to rotate through.

I was basically taking the absolute minimum percent output, which was 20%, if at 0 degrees (horizontal) it would hold there. However if at 90 degrees (straight up), 20% would have no issues rotating. I guess to your point I should be passing in cos(90) which should be 0 and have no feed forward there.

I guess I was just currious if you thinking of finding my arbitary feed-forward was correct. 1. in your answer configured me a little bit. There isn’t a value in percent output mode that’ll hold my arm (my arm rotates around a shoulder).

I’ve seen more overshoot issues with the arm going beyond 90 degrees as well, as its now moving downward. I wonder if I should have any feed forward at all there.

posts.name: Jacob Caporuscio
posts.cooked:
The arbitrary feed forward to counter gravity absolutely needs to be cos(theta) multiplied by the maximum gravity offset needed at horizontal.

Setting percent output to 0 combined with your arbitrary feedforward should keep the arm in position at any point in the rotation.  Then non-zero percent output moves the arm up and down, and that percent output (the first Set() parameter, not the FF) is what you use in your velocity feed-forward and kP calculations.

posts.name: joemost
posts.cooked: Right, that makes sense. Because that is added. Okay thanks

posts.name: Joe Ross
posts.cooked:
joemost:

When it comes to tuning the maximum gravity feed forward, following the guide I found that I needed to run the motor at 20% to be able to hold the 0 horizontal position.

Depending on what motor you’re using, 20% is probably safe but may be on the edge of what you’d want to do long term. If you’re using a motor that has a low thermal mass, it may be worth looking at mechanical solutions, such as increased gearing or counterbalancing.

posts.name: Anand Rajamani
posts.cooked: Adding onto this, 20% is actually quite a lot on some motors. Certainly it’s enough to make the arm fairly difficult to control. Going down to <10% via a gear ratio change massively helps controllability.

posts.name: Bryn Dole - programming mentor FRC 2930
posts.cooked:
Hey, @Oblarg .  I’ve been looking at how to use the WPILib ArmFeedforward class. I’m stuck on how to get values for kSV, sGV, kVVoltSecondPerRad, and kAVoltSecondSquaredPerRad. Do I use SysID? That’s a problem because I don’t have a robot with an arm on it yet. Secondly, how do I avoid SysID breaking my robot? If I was writing my own arm testing code, I’d put in safe parameters and limits. Not having any visibility into what arm code SysID is going to run scares me. Looking at the SysID code, I did see there’s arm simulation code in there. Maybe that’s how SysID characterizes arms?

I started down the road of creating my own arm simulation, starting with the WPILib example. This is super cool. Can I use this to tune ArmFeedForward? I’m not even sure how to go about this in a systematic way. I’m having thoughts about using ML techniques like gradient decent to an optimal solution.

I feel like I’m missing some critical element here.
